I was landing on the Mun when suddenly on touch down rocket almost flip but then stayed balanced on two legs like this :D.
Question is now do I turn SAS off?

[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/GXSbgEK.png[/IMG]
Use your SAS to rock the last leg down, _then_ turn it off.
In comparable situations, I turn of SAS for a minimal amount of time, observe whether this has made the situation better and if so repeat until I stand on all legs. Then one can turn of SAS safely.
On world's with light gravity I'll leave out landing legs all together and land on the engine bell. Saves significant Dv.

My normal solution is simply turn off SAS and use RCS and push down to level out the craft as it is a common issue.
But you have no RCS.
So as others have said F5 and play.
Although I say provide just enough lift with the main engines to straighten out and land.

[quote name='Motokid600']On world's with light gravity I'll leave out landing legs all together and land on the engine bell. Saves significant Dv.[/QUOTE]

The MK2 and MK3 parts have better impact tolerance than landing legs - if you design a ship that can land on them, that's it.

Why would you turn off SAS? It looks perfect the way it is :)

You should have to try to land on Gilly because there is nooooo way to get all legs on the ground.
See for yourself :)
Yes , it looks like a short tap of pitch down (W) should sort it out. The SAS is currently pitching up and slightly yawing left to hold the current attitude...

Stay on two legs. Then optimize for one.
